name: Tetralogy of Fallot
description: Tetralogy of Fallot is a congenital heart defect that consists of four structural abnormalities: a ventricular septal defect, pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, and an overriding aorta. It is the most common cyanotic heart defect.
prognosis: Excellent with surgical repair; >95% survival at 25 years
eli5Summary: Tetralogy of Fallot is when a baby's heart has four problems that make it hard to get enough oxygen to the body, which can make the skin look blue. Doctors can fix these problems with surgery, and most children grow up to live healthy lives.
clinicalSummary: Tetralogy of Fallot is the most common cyanotic congenital heart defect, characterized by four anatomical abnormalities: (1) large VSD, (2) pulmonary stenosis (infundibular, valvar, or both), (3) overriding aorta, and (4) RV hypertrophy. Associated with 22q11.2 deletion in ~15% of cases. Primary repair is typically performed in infancy with closure of VSD and relief of RVOT obstruction. Long-term complications include pulmonary regurgitation requiring valve replacement and arrhythmias. Life-long cardiology follow-up is required.
historicalBackground: Ã‰tienne-Louis Arthur Fallot first described this constellation of defects in 1888. Helen Taussig and Alfred Blalock pioneered the first palliative surgical treatment (Blalock-Taussig shunt) in 1944 at Johns Hopkins. Complete intracardiac repair was first performed by Walton Lillehei in 1954. Modern surgical techniques have made TOF highly treatable with excellent long-term outcomes.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Advanced 3D printing for surgical planning
recentBreakthroughs.description: Patient-specific 3D printed heart models improve surgical precision and outcomes in complex TOF repairs.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Fetal intervention feasibility
recentBreakthroughs.description: Select cases of severe TOF may benefit from fetal balloon pulmonary valvuloplasty to improve postnatal outcomes.

recentBreakthroughs.title: Bioengineered pulmonary valves
recentBreakthroughs.description: Tissue-engineered valves showing growth potential may eliminate need for repeat valve replacements in children.
